questions.question: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding Weber syndrome?

options.A: Lesion is in the oculomotor nerve fascicles and corticospinal fibers
options.B: Hemiplegia is present on the opposite side of the lesion
options.C: There is a lateral squint on the same side of the lesion

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) None of the above Explanation: Lesion is in the oculomotor nerve fascicles and corticospinal fibers (Option A) : Correct because Weber syndrome involves a midbrain lesion affecting the corticospinal tract and the oculomotor nerve fascicles. Hemiplegia is present on the opposite side of the lesion (Option B) : Correct because corticospinal fibers before decussation are damaged, causing contralateral hemiplegia. There is a lateral squint on the same side of the lesion (Option C) : Correct because oculomotor nerve palsy causes the eye to deviate laterally on the ipsilateral side. None of the above (Option D) : Correct answer since no statements are incorrect. Weber Syndrome: Topic Details Anatomy involved Midbrain ventral region (cerebral peduncle) affecting corticospinal tract and oculomotor nerve fascicles Lesion location Basis pedunculi of the midbrain Clinical features Ipsilateral oculomotor palsy (ptosis, pupil dilation, lateral deviation of eye) and contralateral hemiplegia Pathophysiology Damage to corticospinal tract causes contralateral hemiplegia; damage to oculomotor nerve fascicles causes ipsilateral third nerve palsy Signs Contralateral hemiplegia and ipsilateral third nerve pals

questions.question: Which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.A: The PNS relays impulses in neurons away from the viscera.
options.B: The sympathetic nervous system has thoracolumbar outflow.
options.C: Erection is controlled by the parasympathetic nervous system.
options.D: Tearing is regulated by the parasympathetic nervous system.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) The PNS relays impulses in neurons away from the viscera. Explanation: In the parasympathetic system, the relay of impulses happens in neurons that are close to or directly within the target organs (viscera), not away from them. Feature Parasympathetic Nervous System Sympathetic Nervous System Outflow Craniosacral outflow Thoracolumbar outflow (Option B ruled out) Preganglionic Neuron Located in the midbrain, pons, medulla oblongata, and S2–S4 segments of the spinal cord Located in the lateral horn of the spinal cord from Th 1–12 and L 1–2 segments Preganglionic Fibers Longer, myelinated Shorter, myelinated Relay of Impulses Occurs in neurons close to viscera Occurs in neurons a little away from the viscera they supply Postganglionic Fibers Short, nonmyelinated Long, nonmyelinated Neurotransmitter at Preganglionic Endings Acetylcholine Acetylcholine Neurotransmitter at Postganglionic Endings Acetylcholine Adrenaline (except sweat glands, where acetylcholine is used) Postganglionic Supply Only viscera are supplied, do not supply blood vessels of skeletal muscles All viscera are supplied; the exception is the suprarenal gland, which is supplied by preganglionic fibers Heart rate Decreased Increased Blood pressure Mildly decreased Increased Urinary bladder Voiding (decreased tone) Increased sphincter tone Bowel motility Increased Decreased motility Lungs Bronchoconstriction Bronchodilation Sweat glands - Sweating Pupils Constriction Dilation Sexual functions Erection (Option C ruled out) Ejaculation, orgasm Lacrimal glands Tearing (Option D ruled out) - Reference: BD Chaurasia Neuroanatomy, Volume 4, 8th Edition, Page212

questions.question: Where does the hypothalamospinal tract terminate before synapsing with the second-order neurons?

options.C: Intermediolateral cell column of the spinal cord
options.D: Posterior horn of the spinal cord

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Intermediolateral cell column of the spinal cord Explanation: The hypothalamospinal tract terminates in the intermediolateral cell column (IML) of the spinal cord, where it synapses with the second-order sympathetic neurons. Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition, Page 304.

questions.question: All of the following options are branches of the internal carotid artery except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Anterior inferior cerebellar artery Explanation: Anterior inferior cerebellar artery is a branch of the basilar artery. The internal carotid artery is divided into three parts based on its course. Petrous part Cavernous part Intracranial part Branches of the intracranial part of internal carotid artery: Branches Areas supplied Ophthalmic artery (Option A ruled out) Contents of orbit Posterior communicating artery (Option C ruled out) Crus cerebri, optic tract, hypophysis and hypothalamus Anterior choroidal artery (Option B ruled out) Crus cerebri and choroid plexus of inferior horn of lateral ventricle Anterior cerebral artery Deep branches supply part of the internal capsule and the basal nuclei. Cortical branches supply the medial surface of the hemisphere. Middle cerebral artery Deep or perforating branches supply the anterior limb of the internal capsule and part of the basal nuclei. Cortical branches supply temporal, frontal and parietal lobe. Branches in the petrous part are caroticotympanic artery and pterygoid artery Branches in the cavernous part are meningohypophyseal trunk and the inferolateral trunk Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 42nd Edition, Pages 415-418 BD Chaurasia Neuroanatomy, Volume 4, 8th Edition, Pages 189, 190.

questions.question: A transverse section of the medulla oblongata at the level of the motor (pyramidal) decussation reveals modifications to the typical spinal cord structure. Which of the following changes is observed at this level?

options.A: Formation of the medial lemniscus from second-order axons
options.B: Crossing of corticospinal fibres from the anterior funiculi
options.C: Presence of the vestibular nuclei near the fourth ventricle
options.D: Appearance of the inferior olivary complex lateral to the pyramid

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Crossing of corticospinal fibres from the anterior funiculi Explanation: At the level of the motor decussation, corticospinal fibres cross from the anterior funiculi to the contralateral side, a hallmark of this level. Internal Organization of the Medulla Oblongata 1. Transverse Section at Motor (Pyramidal) Decussation Level The inferior medulla adapts to accommodate brainstem nuclei and fibres. Corticospinal fibres cross at the motor decussation, decreasing the pyramid size. (Option B) Ventral grey column divides into: Supraspinal nucleus (first cervical nerve origin, continuous with the hypoglossal nerve nucleus). Nucleus of the accessory nerve (aligned with the nucleus ambiguus). Surrounding tracts : Ventral corticospinal tract (medioventral). Ventral and dorsal spinocerebellar tracts (dorsolateral). Dorsal grey column modified by the presence of the nucleus gracilis and cuneatus, continuous with spinal structures. 2. Transverse Section at Sensory Decussation (Dorsal Column–Medial Lemniscus System) Nuclei and tracts present : Nucleus gracilis and nucleus cuneatus, receiving first-order afferent fibres. Second-order axons (internal arcuate fibres) cross the midline as sensory decussation to form the medial lemniscus. (Option A ruled out) Medial lemniscus : Located dorsal to the pyramid. Inferior olivary complex appears lateral to it. (Option D ruled out) Other key structures : Dorsal spinocerebellar and trigeminal nerve tracts, reticular formation, corticospinal tract, medial longitudinal fasciculus, and tectospinal tract. 3. Transverse Section at Caudal End of Fourth Ventricle Grey matter increases due to nuclei associated with cranial nerves IX, X, XI, and VIII. Key nuclei : Inferior olivary complex. Hypoglossal nucleus, vagus dorsal motor nucleus, salivatory nuclei, nucleus solitarius, and vestibular nuclei. (Option C ruled out) Restiform body forms the dorsal lateral border, carrying afferent fibers (spinocerebellar and olivocerebellar tracts). Other structures : Spinal trigeminal nucleus, nucleus ambiguus, reticular formation. Spinocerebellar, spinothalamic, and rubrospinal tracts ventral to the olivary complex and pyramid.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct match of brainstem components with the respective cranial nerve nuclei that originate from them? Column A Column B a. Midbrain 1. Trigeminal nerve b. Pons 2. Oculomotor nerve c. Medulla oblongata 3. Glossopharyngeal nerve d. Pontomedullary junction 4. Facial nerve
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) a-2, b-1, c-3, d-4 Explanation: Components of brainstem Cranial nerves nuclei Midbrain Oculomotor (III) and trochlear (IV) Pons Trigeminal (V) Medulla oblongata Glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), cranial accessory (XIcr) and hypoglossal (XII) Pontomedullary junction Abducens (VI), facial (VII) and vestibulocochlear (VIII) Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 42nd Edition, Page 442

questions.question: Which of the following findings is not a clinical manifestation of Wallenberg syndrome?

options.C: Ipsilateral facial pain and temperature loss
options.D: Contralateral body pain and temperature loss

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Contralateral ataxia Explanation: Ipsilateral ataxia is seen in Wallenburg sybdrome due to damage to inferior cerebellar peduncle, spino cerebellar tracts, and part of cerebellum. Wallenburg sybdrome: Also known as Lateral medullary syndrome Pathology: Blockage of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. It supplies areas behind the inferior olivary nucleus. Damage to the lateral segment of the medulla posterior to the inferior olivary nucleus. Clinical manifestation: Anatomical location Presenting clinical feature Nucleus ambiguous gives fibers to IX, X, and XI cranial nerves Ipsilateral paralysis of muscles of the soft palate, pharynx, and larynx Spinal nucleus and spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve Ipsilateral facial pain and temperature loss (Option C ruled out) Lateral spinothalamic tract Contralateral body pain and temperature loss (Option D ruled out) Vestibular nuclei Vertigo Inferior cerebellar peduncle, spino cerebellar tracts, and part of cerebellum Ipsilateral ataxia (Option A) Sympathetic fibres descend from the hypothalamus to cells in the lateral horn of spinal cord Horner’s syndrome (Option B ruled out) , comprising ptosis, enophthalmos, miosis, and anhydrosis Reference: BD Chaurasia Neuroanatomy, Volume 4, 8th Edition, Pages 106, 107

questions.question: Which of the following nerve palsy would suggest a lesion affecting the structures within the interpeduncular fossa?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Oculomotor nerve Explanation: A lesion affecting the interpeduncular fossa could damage the oculomotor nerve (CN III), which emerges from this region, leading to diplopia and ptosis. Interpeduncular fossa It is a deep depression of the ventral surface of the midbrain between the two crura cerebri. The lateral wall of the interpeduncular fossa bears the oculomotor sulcus, from which rootlets of the oculomotor nerve emerge from the brainstem and aggregate into a single fascicle. (Option C) Contents Oculomotor nerve (Option C) Circle of Willis Bifurcation of the basilar artery Peduncular segments of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) and superior cerebellar artery, (SCA) Medial and lateral posterior choroidal arteries Basal vein of Rosenthal Glossopharyngeal nerve (Option A): and vagus nerve (Option B): The rootlets of the cranial nerves IX (Glossopharyngeal) and X (vagus) emerge through the posterolateral fissure, behind the olive. Hypoglossal nerve (Option D): The rootlets of the hypoglossal nerve emerge from the anterolateral sulcus between the pyramid and the olive. Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 42nd Edition, Pages 456 BD Chaurasia Neuroanatomy, Volume 4, 8th Edition, Pages 187, 190, 100 Interpeduncular Fossa - an overview | ScienceDirect

questions.question: Which among the following options is correctly matched for the alphabet labeled in the below image?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Olive Explanation: Image in the question represents the ventral surface of the brainstem. Alphabet D labelled in the image is olive, a pair of prominent oval structures on either side of the medullary pyramids in the medulla. Ventral surface (Frontal view) of the brainstem: Alphabet C is Pyramid Alphabet A is the basilar sulcus of pons Alphabet B is occulomotor nerve

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with a severe infection of the face. Which of the following venous structures could allow the infection to spread to the cavernous sinus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Inferior ophthalmic vein Explanation: The inferior ophthalmic vein connects the facial veins to the cavernous sinus, making it a route for the spread of infections from the face. Cavernous sinus: It is two large venous spaces situated in the middle cranial fossa, on either side of the body of the sphenoid bone. Important structures related to Cavernous Sinus: Tributaries or Incoming Channels From the orbit: Superior ophthalmic vein Inferior ophthalmic vein- connects facial vein to cavernous sinus (Option B) Central vein of the retina- drains either into the superior ophthalmic vein or directly into the cavernous sinus. From the brain: Superficial middle cerebral vein Inferior cerebral veins from the temporal lobe From the meninges Sphenoparietal sinus Frontal trunk of the middle meningeal- drains into the pterygoid plexus or the sphenoparietal or cavernous sinus Draining Channels or Communications Into the transverse sinus through the superior petrosal sinus. (Option A ruled out) Into the internal jugular vein through the inferior petrosal sinus. (Option C ruled out) Into the pterygoid plexus of veins through the emissary veins. Into the facial vein through the superior ophthalmic vein. The right and left cavernous sinuses communicate with each other through the anterior and posterior intercavernous sinuses and the basilar plexus of veins. (Option D ruled out) Note: All these communications are valveless, and blood flows in both directions. Note : The superior ophthalmic vein has bidirectional flow, whereas the inferior ophthalmic vein has unidirectional blood flow. Dangerous areas of face: (Upper lip and lower part of the nose) The facial vein communicates with the cavernous sinus through the pterygoid venous plexus, superior ophthalmic vein, and inferior ophthalmic vein. Infections from the face spread in a retrograde direction and cause thrombosis of the cavernous sinus.

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with symptoms of headache and visual disturbances. Imaging studies reveal a large clot in the superior sagittal sinus. Which of the following statements about the superior sagittal sinus is correct?

options.A: It drains directly into the internal jugular vein.
options.B: It runs along the midline, attached to the falx cerebri, and drains into the confluence of sinuses.
options.C: It is located in the falx cerebelli and connects with the occipital sinus.
options.D: It receives blood from the diploic veins within the cranial bones.

questions.explanation: confluence of sinuses. Correct Answer: B) It runs along the midline, attached to the falx cerebri, and drains into the confluence of sinuses. Explanation: The superior sagittal sinus runs along the midline, is attached to the falx cerebri, and typically drains into the confluence of sinuses. Dural Venous Sinuses: Anatomical Features and Location: Network of venous channels: Drain blood from the brain and cranial bones. Location: Between endosteal and meningeal layers of the dura mater. Structure: Lined by endothelium, lacks valves and muscular tissue. Development: Arise from venous plexuses, often retain plexiform structure. Sinuses and Connections: Sinus Location Drainage Superior sagittal sinus (Option B) Along midline, attached to falx cerebri (Option C ruled out) Confluence of sinuses, usually right side (Option A ruled out) Inferior sagittal sinus Lower edge of falx cerebri Continues as straight sinus Straight sinus Junction of falx cerebri and tentorium cerebelli Drains into left transverse sinus Transverse sinuses Along tentorium cerebelli Continue as sigmoid sinuses Sigmoid sinuses From transverse sinuses Becomes internal jugular vein Occipital sinus In falx cerebelli Drains into confluence of sinuses Cavernous sinuses Plexiform, on either side of sphenoid bone Receives blood from ophthalmic veins, drains via superior and inferior petrosal sinuses Intercavernous sinuses Connects the two cavernous sinuses - Superior petrosal sinuses Drains cavernous sinus into transverse sinus - Inferior petrosal sinuses Drains cavernous sinus into internal jugular vein - Sphenoparietal sinuses Under lesser wings of sphenoid bone Drains into cavernous sinus Basilar sinus and plexus Over clivus, connects cavernous and petrosal sinuses - Marginal sinus Encircles foramen magnum Connects with basilar plexus and occipital sinus Tributaries: Cerebral veins: Drain brain parenchyma. Diploic veins: Within cranial bones. (Option D ruled out- The superior sagittal sinus does not receive blood from diploic veins; these veins are tributaries to other sinuses. ) Meningeal veins: Drain dura mater. Emissary veins: Connect intracranial and extracranial veins. Clinical Significance: Spread of infection: Emissary veins can facilitate infection spread from extracranial sites to sinuses. Venous sinus thrombosis: Blood clots can obstruct drainage, leading to complications such as venous infarction and hemorrhage. Surgical considerations: Knowledge of sinus anatomy is crucial for avoiding injury and hemorrhage during neurosurgery. Additional Insights: Variability: Sinus size and connections can vary, especially in infancy. Imaging techniques: Angiography, MR venography, and CT venography are vital for visualizing sinuses and variations. Innervation: Cranial dura mater is mainly innervated by trigeminal nerve and upper cervical nerves, explaining headache symptoms from dura stimulation.

questions.question: A 56-year-old patient presents with difficulty speaking, swallowing, and hoarseness of voice. On examination, there is noticeable wasting of one side of the tongue and weakness in the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. The patient also exhibits contralateral hemiplegia and contralateral loss of sensation. Which of the following lesions is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Medullary infarct Explanation: Medullary infarct is the most likely cause as it affects the medulla oblongata, leading to symptoms like bulbar palsy (difficulty speaking and swallowing), tongue wasting, muscle weakness, contralateral hemiplegia , and loss of sensation. These are consistent with the involvement of both ascending and descending tracts through the medulla. Lower Brainstem Lesions Lower brainstem lesions affect the medulla oblongata and can lead to various neurological symptoms. These are often seen as bulbar palsy . Common Symptoms: Dysarthria: Difficulty speaking due to impaired control of tongue, lips, and vocal cords. Dysphagia (CN IX): Difficulty swallowing caused by weakened throat muscles. Dysphonia: Voice problems, such as hoarseness. Tongue Wasting (CN XII): Shrinkage and weakness of one side of the tongue, leading to deviation. Muscle Weakness/Wasting: Affects sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles (CN XI) , impacting head turning and shoulder elevation. Additional Symptoms: Contralateral Hemiplegia: Paralysis or weakness on the opposite side of the body due to corticospinal tract involvement. Contralateral Hemianesthesia: Loss of sensation on the opposite side of the body from anterolateral system or dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway involvement. Cerebellar Signs: Coordination and balance difficulties from cerebellar afferent or efferent pathway damage. Nystagmus: Involuntary eye movements indicating vestibular pathway disruptions. Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia: Impaired horizontal eye movements due to medial longitudinal fasciculus lesions. Causes: Space-Occupying Tumours: Examples include meningiomas, vestibular schwannomas, or metastatic carcinomas. Intrinsic Diseases: Gliomas: Tumours from glial cells. Demyelination: Such as in multiple sclerosis. Stroke: Resulting from blood flow interruption. Multiple sclerosis (Option A) primarily causes demyelination and could present with various neurological symptoms but is less likely to produce isolated medullary symptoms with the specific combination of deficits described. Meningioma of the cerebellum (Option B) would more likely cause cerebellar symptoms rather than a specific combination of bulbar palsy and contralateral deficits. Vestibular schwannoma (Option D) typically presents with hearing loss and balance issues rather than the described bulbar symptoms and contralateral deficits. Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 42nd Edition, Pages 462, 438.

questions.question: Which of the following accurately describes the corticonuclear tract? contralateral projection.

options.A: It terminates exclusively in the spinal cord with an ipsilateral projection.
options.B: It descends through the internal capsule and pons, terminating on cranial nerve nuclei with a
options.C: It controls involuntary movements of the head and neck muscles.
options.D: The term "corticobulbar" is more accurate than "corticonuclear" for describing its function.

questions.explanation: nuclei with a contralateral projection. Correct Answer: B) It descends through the internal capsule and pons, terminating on cranial nerve nuclei with a contralateral projection. Explanation: The corticonuclear tract fibres descend from the cerebral cortex through the internal capsule and pons. They then terminate on cranial nerve nuclei in the brainstem. The fibres exhibit a contralateral projection pattern, meaning they cross the midline of the brainstem to innervate the nuclei on the opposite side of the brainstem. Corticonuclear Tract: Origin and Pathway: Arises from neurons in the cerebral cortex Descends through: (Option B) Subcortical white matter Genu and posterior limb of the internal capsule Ventral midbrain (crus cerebri) Pons (fragmented into fascicles by pontocerebellar fibers) Termination: (Option A ruled out) Unlike corticospinal fibres, terminates on cranial nerve nuclei and brainstem nuclei: (Option B) Midbrain Pons Medulla oblongata In the medulla, projects to: Nucleus ambiguus Hypoglossal nucleus Exhibits a contralateral projection pattern (crosses midline to opposite brainstem side) Function: Controls voluntary movements (Option C ruled out) of head and neck muscles, including: Facial expression Chewing Swallowing Tongue movement Speech Terminology: (Option D ruled out) "Bulbar" (from "bulb," an outdated term for medulla oblongata) is less accurate than "corticonuclear" "Corticonuclear" is preferred as it covers a broader range of brainstem nuclei beyond the medulla Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 42nd Edition, Pages 444, 445, 389, 390.

questions.question: At the level of the facial colliculus, the fibres of which cranial nerves form a loop around the abducens nucleus, creating the colliculus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Facial nerve Explanation: The fibres of the facial nerve curve dorsally around the abducens nucleus, forming the facial colliculus. Internal Organization of the Pons Section Dorsal Aspect Ventral Aspect Facial Colliculus Level Medial longitudinal fasciculus: beneath fourth ventricle, lateral to median sulcus Medial lemniscus: ovoid bundle in ventral pontine tegmentum Abducens nucleus: sends fibres ventro-laterally and caudally Trapezoid body fibers and nuclei cross midline along medial lemniscus Facial nerve nucleus: ventral, lateral, caudal to abducens nucleus Central tegmental tract: longitudinally through mid-pontine tegmentum Facial nerve fibres curve dorsally and laterally over abducens nucleus (facial colliculus) (Option C) Pontine nuclei: transverse pontocerebellar fibres form contralateral middle cerebellar peduncle Inferior cerebellar peduncle (restiform and juxtarestiform bodies): superolateral to vestibular nuclei Descending fibres (frontopontine, corticospinal, parieto-temporo-occipito-pontine): longitudinally through basal pons Trigeminal Nerve Nuclei Level Superior cerebellar peduncle: lateral wall of fourth ventricle Medial and lateral lemnisci: convex lemniscal arch, separating tegmentum from basal pons Superior medullary velum: roof of fourth ventricle Trapezoid body fibres and nuclei: curve across midline in ventral tegmentum Superior fovea: lateral margin of fourth ventricle, overlies trigeminal nerve nuclei Mesencephalic tract of trigeminal nerve: dorsolateral tegmentum Glossopharyngeal nerve (Option A) : This nerve is not involved at the level of the facial colliculus. Trigeminal nerve (Option B) : The trigeminal nerve nuclei are located higher in the mid-pons, not at the level of the facial colliculus. Hypoglossal nerve (Option D) : This nerve is located in the medulla, not the pons, and does not contribute to the formation of the facial colliculus.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is associated with lesions at the level marked in the midbrain?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: The superior colliculus is marked in the above image and all the given syndromes are associated with lesions at this level. Transverse section at level of the superior colliculus in midbrain Grey Matter Oculomotor nerve nucleus with Edinger Westphal nucleus in the ventromedial part. The mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve in the lateral part. Superior colliculus: Afferents from the retina (visual), and various other centres. Efferents to the spinal cord (tectospinal tract). Reflex movements of the eyes, and the head and neck in response to visual stimuli. Pretectal nucleus: Location: Deep to the superolateral part of the superior colliculus. Afferents from the lateral roots of the optic tract. Efferents to the Edinger-Westphal nuclei of both sides. Part of the pathway for the light reflex and the consensual reflex. It causes an Argyll Robertson pupil in which the light reflex is lost but the accommodation reflex remains intact. Red nucleus: Afferents from the superior cerebellar peduncle, globus pallidus, subthalamic nucleus and cerebral cortex. Efferents to the spinal cord (rubrospinal tract), reticular formation, thalamus, olivary nucleus, subthalamic nucleus. Plays a role in inhibitory influence on muscle tone. Substantia nigra White Matter Crus cerebri Tegmentum Tectum shows the posterior commissure connecting the two superior colliculi. Syndromes associated with lesions at the level of superior colliculus: Weber’s syndrome: Involves III nerve nucleus and corticospinal fibres. Features:

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not correct regarding lemniscus?

options.A: It is a collection of axons running in the spinal cord
options.B: The lateral lemniscus is a part of the auditory pathway
options.C: Spinal leminiscus is affected in wallenberg syndrome
options.D: Spinal lemniscus carries pain and temperature sensation

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) It is a Collection of axons running in the spinal cord Explanation: Lemniscus is a collection of axons running in the brainstem. Lemniscus Collection of axons running in the brainstem (Option A) Four types (MTSL) M edial lemniscus L ateral lemniscus T rigeminal lemniscus S pinal lemniscus Medial lemniscus Continuation of dorsal column (nucleus gracilis and cuneatus) Sensations it carries are: Pressure Vibration Tactile discrimination Stereognosis Conscious proprioception Lateral lemniscus Formed by fibres arising in nuclei lying in close relation to the trapezoid body (superior olivary nucleus and nucleus of trapezoid body). It carries auditory information from the cochlear nuclei. (Option B ruled out) Trigeminal lemniscus Contains fibres arising in the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve and traveling to the thalamus. Extends into the midbrain, medulla, and the spinal cord Spinal lemniscus Carries pain and temperature. (Option D ruled out) Lateral medullary ischemia- Wallenberg syndrome (Option C ruled out) Occurs due to blockage of posterior inferior cerebellar artery. It supplies areas behind the inferior olivary nucleus. It involves spinal leminiscus (c/l loss of pain and temp from body) and i/l loss of pain and temp from face (due to involvement of spinal nucleus of V nerve Injury to leminiscus always leads to C/l loss of function Reference: BD Chaurasia Neuroanatomy, Volume 4, 8th Edition, Page 103, 106, 108, 109. Neuroanatomy, Brainstem - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

questions.question: A 55-year-old man diagnosed with B12 deficiency presents with difficulty maintaining balance. On examination, he shows a loss of vibration and fine touch sensation in his lower limbs, while pain and temperature sensations are intact. Which of the following pathways is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.explanation: responsible for transmitting fine touch, vibration, and proprioception from the lower limbs. B12 deficiency can lead to subacute combined degeneration, affecting this pathway and causing the sensory deficits seen in the patient. Tracts of the spinal cord Column Descending tracts Ascending tracts Anterior white column Anterior corticospinal, vestibulospinal, tectospinal, medial reticulospinal Anterior spinothalamic Lateral white column Lateral corticospinal, rubrospinal, lateral reticulospinal, hypothalamospinal Lateral spinothalamic, anterior spinocerebellar, posterior spinocerebellar, spinotectal Posterior white column(Dorsal column) • Fasciculus gracilis (tract of Goll) • Fasciculus cuneatus (tract of Burdach) Dorsal Column (Posterior Column-Medial Lemniscus Pathway): Category Details Components Fasciculus Gracilis: Carries sensory information from the lower limbs (Option C) Fasciculus Cuneatus: Carries sensory information from the upper limbs Sensations Pressure Tactile discrimination Vibration Conscious Proprioception Stereognosis Neuronal Pathway 1st Order Neuron: Located in the dorsal root ganglion 2nd Order Neuron: Located in the medulla oblongata 3rd Order Neuron: Located in the thalamus Spinothalamic Tract (Spinal Lemniscus System): Category Details Types (Options A & B ruled out) Lateral Spinothalamic Tract: Carries pain and temperature sensations Ventral Spinothalamic Tract: Carries crude touch and pressure sensations Pathway 1st Order Neuron: Located in the dorsal root ganglion 2nd Order Neuron: Located in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord 3rd Order Neuron: Located in the thalamus Pyramidal Tract (Corticospinal Tract): Involved in voluntary motor control (Option D ruled out) . Category Details Types Lateral Corticospinal Tract: Contains about 90% of the corticospinal fibers Ventral Corticospinal Tract: Contains the remaining fibers Function Controls fine and skilled voluntary motor activities, such as threading a needle Works in conjunction with the corticobulbar (corticonuclear) tracts Neuronal Pathway Receives axons from the cerebrum (upper motor neuron, UMN type of fibers) Effects of Damage Damage to Pyramidal System: Causes spastic paralysis of skeletal muscles below the level of the lesion Damage to Lower Motor Neurons: Causes flaccid paralysis at the level of the lesion

questions.question: Which of the following arteries is primarily responsible for supplying the sublenticular part of the internal capsule, which carries auditory fibres?

options.A: Recurrent branch of anterior cerebral artery
options.B: Direct branches from the internal carotid

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Branch of anterior choroidal Explanation: Sublenticular part of the internal capsule is supplied by the branch of anterior choroidal artery and the branch of the posterior cerebral artery. It carries ascending auditory fibres from temporal lobe to thalamus. Vascular supply of internal capsule Sublenticular part of the internal capsule is supplied by the branch of anterior choroidal artery and branch of posterior cerebral artery. Recurrent branch of anterior cerebral artery (Option A): Supplies anterior limb of the internal capsule. Direct branches from the internal carotid (Option B): Supplies genu of the internal capsule. Branch of posterior communicating (Option D): Supplies genu and part of the posterior limb of the internal capsule. Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 42nd Edition, Page 420 BD Chaurasia Neuroanatomy, Volume 4, 8th Edition, Pages 163,164.

questions.question: A 62-year-old presents with sudden-onset left-sided weakness, primarily affecting the arm and face. On examination, he has difficulty with speech, displaying both expressive and receptive aphasia. He also shows left-sided facial drooping and an inability to move his left upper limb effectively. Sensation is relatively intact in his lower limb. Which artery is most likely affected?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Middle cerebral artery (MCA) Explanation: The MCA supplies the lateral aspects of the cerebral hemispheres, including the motor and sensory cortices controlling the face, upper limb, and speech areas (in the dominant hemisphere). The patient's symptoms of weakness in the face and arm, combined with aphasia, strongly suggest an MCA stroke , as this artery is responsible for these regions. An ACA stroke typically affects the lower limbs, and a PCA stroke would more likely present with visual field defects or sensory disturbances. Artery Affected Areas Involved Clinical Manifestations Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) (Option A) Medial surface of the frontal and parietal lobes, corpus callosum Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (lower limb > upper limb) Urinary incontinence, Personality changes (frontal lobe involvement), Transcortical motor aphasia (dominant hemisphere) Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) (Option C) Lateral surface of the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes, basal ganglia, internal capsule Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (face and upper limb > lower limb) Aphasia (dominant hemisphere), Hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere), Homonymous hemianopia Gaze preference towards the side of the lesion Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA) (Option B) Occipital lobe, inferior part of temporal lobe, thalamus Contralateral homonymous hemianopia , Visual agnosia , Thalamic pain syndrome, Cortical blindness (if bilateral), Memory deficits (if temporal lobe is involved) Reference: Harrison’s principles of internal medicine, 20th Edition, Page 420.

questions.question: Identify the artery highlighted in blue in the following image.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Anterior communicating artery Explanation: The anterior communicating artery connects the two anterior cerebral arteries and forms part of the Circle of Willis. This artery plays a critical role in allowing collateral blood flow between the left and right sides of the cerebral circulation.

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with Horner’s syndrome, but notably, the patient does not exhibit anhidrosis. Based on the absence of anhidrosis, which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Third-order neuron (postganglionic) Explanation: The absence of anhidrosis in Horner's syndrome suggests that the lesion is likely located in the postganglionic (third-order neuron) segment of the oculosympathetic pathway. The sweat glands are primarily innervated by sympathetic fibers that branch off earlier. Hence, in third-order Horner's syndrome, if the disruption occurs after these fibers have already branched off, sweating pathways are unaffected, and anhidrosis does not occur. In contrast, anhidrosis is always present in first-order or second-order Horner's syndrome.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about prevertebral/paravertebral ganglia is/are true? Prevertebral ganglia are also known as collateral ganglia. Prevertebral ganglia are a part of the parasympathetic nervous system. Paravertebral ganglia supply the abdominal viscera. The celiac ganglion is a paravertebral ganglion.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) I only Explanation: Prevertebral ganglia are also known as collateral ganglia. Prevertebral ganglia and paravertebral ganglia both are part of the sympathetic nervous system , not the parasympathetic nervous system. Paravertebral ganglia (sympathetic trunk ganglia) primarily supply the body wall and limbs, while prevertebral ganglia (e.g., celiac ganglion) supply the abdominal viscera . The celiac ganglion is a prevertebral (collateral) ganglion , not a paravertebral ganglion. Characteristic Prevertebral Ganglia Paravertebral Ganglia Alternate Names Also known as collateral ganglia or preaortic ganglia. (Statement I) Also known as sympathetic chain ganglia. Sympathetic Pathway Both are part of the sympathetic nervous system. (Statement II ruled out) Location Anterior to the aorta, close to major arteries like the celiac, superior mesenteric, and inferior mesenteric arteries. Adjacent to the vertebral column, forming sympathetic chains on either side of the spine. Structure Associated with the abdominal aorta and related to major arteries. Forms a chain along the spine, with ganglia in the cervical, thoracic, lumbar, sacral, and coccygeal regions. Function Supplies abdominal and pelvic organs, controls visceral functions like peristalsis and secretion. ( Statement III ruled out) Supplies the thoracic viscera, blood vessels, skin, sweat glands, and arrector pili muscles. Preganglionic Fibers Receive preganglionic fibers from the splanchnic nerves (e.g., greater, lesser, least splanchnic). Receive preganglionic fibers from the spinal cord segments (T1-L2) via white rami communicantes. Postganglionic Fibers Postganglionic fibers form plexuses like the celiac and hypogastric plexus, supplying abdominal and pelvic organs. Postganglionic fibers distributed via grey rami communicantes to spinal nerves and target skin, blood vessels, and thoracic viscera. Notable Ganglia Includes the celiac, superior mesenteric, inferior mesenteric, and aorticorenal ganglia. (Statement IV ruled out) Includes cervical, thoracic, lumbar, sacral ganglia, and ganglion impar.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.A: Preganglionic fibers in both the sympathetic and parasympathetic systems are myelinated.
options.B: Postganglionic fibers in both the sympathetic and parasympathetic systems are unmyelinated
options.C: Most sweat glands are sympathetic and adrenergic.
options.D: Acetylcholine is a neurotransmitter found in sympathetic ganglia.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Most sweat glands are sympathetic and adrenergic. Explanation: Most sweat glands (eccrine) are sympathetic and cholinergic, not adrenergic. Only a few sweat glands (apocrine) are sympathetic and adrenergic. ANS - Effectors: General Visceral Efferent (GVE) Smooth muscles Cardiac muscles Glands Neurotransmitters and Efferent Innervation: Autonomic Efferent Innervation - GVE Neuron Bodies: Lateral horn cells of the spinal cord Can be sympathetic or parasympathetic neurons Predominantly sympathetic neurons Sacral spinal cord: Parasympathetic neurons are also present Preganglionic Fibers: Myelinated (both in sympathetic and parasympathetic systems) (Option A ruled out) White in color Postganglionic Fibers: Unmyelinated (both in sympathetic and parasympathetic systems) (Option B ruled out) Grey in color Neurotransmitters: Acetylcholine: Found in parasympathetic and sympathetic ganglia (Option D ruled out) Effector Organ Responses: Parasympathetic: Cholinergic (acetylcholine) Sympathetic: Adrenergic (epinephrine and norepinephrine) (rare) Sweat Glands: Most sweat glands (eccrine) are sympathetic and cholinergic Few sweat glands (apocrine) are sympathetic and adrenergic Reference: BD Chaurasia Neuroanatomy, Volume 4, 8th Edition, Page 207 - 212

questions.question: A 64-year-old woman presents with progressive weakness in her left leg. On examination, you observe that her left leg has decreased muscle tone, and shows significant muscle atrophy. Given these findings, which of the following additional signs is likely to be present?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Fasciculations Explanation: The patient’s findings of decreased muscle tone, muscle atrophy, and flaccid paralysis are indicative of Lower Motor Neuron (LMN) involvement. In LMN lesions, you typically see muscle atrophy and decreased muscle tone along with absent deep tendon reflexes. Fasciculations, which are involuntary muscle twitches, are a common additional sign in LMN lesions due to denervation of the muscle fibers. Feature LMN Paralysis UMN Paralysis Muscle Tone Decreased Increased Type of Paralysis Flaccid Spastic (Option C ruled out) Muscle Atrophy Occurs later No atrophy Reaction of Degeneration Seen Not seen Tendon Reflexes Absent Exaggerated (Option A ruled out) Side of Affected Body Ipsilateral Contralateral Babinski Sign Negative Positive (Option B ruled out) Fasciculation Present Absent Reference: BD Chaurasia Neuroanatomy, Volume 4, 8th Edition, Page 51

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient presents following a fall from a ladder. The patient exhibits specific neurological symptoms: loss of pain and temperature sensation in the left leg, difficulty identifying the position of the right leg with eyes closed, and complete loss of sensation at the T12 level of the trunk on the right. Which of the following statements is false for this condition?

options.A: Loss of proprioception in the right leg occurs due right dorsal column.
options.B: Loss of pain in the left leg occurs due to the left spinothalamic tract.
options.C: Damage to the ventral nerve roots at the T12 level results in loss of sensation.
options.D: Spastic paralysis of the right leg

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Loss of pain in the left leg occurs due to the left spinothalamic tract. of the spinal cord. In Brown-Séquard syndrome, pain, and temperature sensations are lost on the opposite side of the body from the lesion due to the crossing of the spinothalamic tract fibers. Therefore, loss of pain in the left leg would be due to damage to the right spinothalamic tract, not the left. Brown-Sequard syndrome Below the Level of Lesion: Ipsilateral Upper Motor Neuron Paralysis: Due to damage to the pyramidal tract (corticospinal tract) (Option D ruled out) . Ipsilateral Loss of Conscious Proprioceptive Sensations: Caused by damage to the posterior white column (Option A ruled out) . Contralateral Loss of Pain and Temperature Sensations: Due to damage to the lateral spinothalamic tract and anterior spinothalamic tract. At the Level of Lesion: (Option C ruled out) Ipsilateral Lower Motor Neuron Paralysis: Resulting from damage to the ventral nerve roots. Ipsilateral Anesthesia Over the Skin of the Segment: Due to injury to the ventral nerve roots. Above the Level of Lesion: Ipsilateral Hyperesthesia: Resulting from irritation of the dorsal nerve roots.
